Feature: Is there a phonologically free antipassive marker ("particle" or "auxiliary")?
Function: antipassive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
Clarifying Comments: Antipassive markers detransitivize verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique complement. In languages that have ergative alignment, this means that the ergative argument (A) becomes absolutive (S). Antipassive markers often also have other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, it is possible to define this feature as targeting any intransitivising marker that is not a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets phonologically independent particles or auxiliaries marking antipassive clauses.

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked inverse on verbs?
Clarifying Comments: Inverse systems (as defined in this project) are based on an animacy or person hierarchy (e.g. first/second person > third person > cats > dogs > other animals > inanimates). Languages can have markers on transitive verbs that indicate whether the agent(-like argument) of the clause is higher on this hierarchy than the patient(-like argument) [= direct marker], or whether the reverse is true, i.e. that the patient outranks the agent on the hierarchy [= inverse marker]. An example would be 'man INV-bite dog' to mean 'the dog bit the man'. Note that in some languages, there are portmanteau morphemes that both function as a person index on verbs and as direct/inverse markers, so different person indexes are used based on where the agent and patient are located relative to each other on the hierarchy. This counts as a 1 for this question. This question targets phonologically bound inverse markers on lexical verbs.

Feature: Are there morphological cases for non-pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Clarifying Comments: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is phonologically bound (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S NPs, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.
Definition: Is there case marking for core nominal NPs (i.e., S, A or O function)?

Feature: Are there morphological cases for pronominal core arguments (i.e. S/A/P)?
Clarifying Comments: This question is about independent pronouns only; indexes are irrelevant here. Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is phonologically bound (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Core arguments are those having S, A or P function. If a bound marker distinguishes S from non-S pronouns, this counts as a 1. Optional marking and marking with portmanteau morphemes (e.g. a marker both indicates that a noun phrase is plural and that it has P function) also count.
Definition: Is there case marking for core pronouns?

Feature: Is there any accusative alignment of flagging?
Clarifying Comments: Do S, A, and P arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with "1" if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. only nouns or only pronouns, or a particular tense or person) shows accusative alignment.<CR><CR>Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.<CR><CR>Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includes what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).<CR><CR>Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.

Feature: Is there any ergative alignment of flagging?
Clarifying Comments: Do S, P, and A arguments differ in terms of flagging (case and adposition marking)? Reply with "1" if any of the flagging subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows ergative alignment.<CR><CR>Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.<CR><CR>Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).<CR><CR>Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.

Feature: Is there any neutral alignment of flagging?
Clarifying Comments: Are S, A, and P arguments flagged identically? In case of split systems, reply with "1" if any of the subsystems (e.g. a particular tense or person) shows neutral alignment. Reply with "1" if none of the three arguments is overtly flagged (i.e. if all three arguments are zero-marked).<CR><CR>Although alignment types are occasionally associated with entire languages (e.g. when one says that "Dyirbal is an ergative language"), they in fact apply only to individual constructions. The constructions which can be observed in almost every clause are  flagging and indexing.<CR><CR>Flagging is a relatively new term (introduced in Haspelmath 2005). It covers any kind of argument marking on the argument itself. It includs what is traditionally referred to as case or adposition marking or by a more general term of *dependent marking* (on the clause level) (Nichols 1986).<CR><CR>Indexing (covered in GB089-GB094) is the marking of arguments on the verb. It is often referred to as agreement or cross-referencing or pronominal marking or head marking on the clause level in Nichols' terms.

Feature: Are there prepositions?
Clarifying Comments: Prepositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They precede the noun phrase they occur with. Proclitics (case markers that only occur noun phrase initially) count as prepositions in Grambank. This means that phonological boundness is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as prepositions. If there is only one preposition, this is enough for a 1 here.

Feature: Are there postpositions?
Clarifying Comments: Postpositions mark core or oblique noun phrases. They follow the noun phrase they occur with. Enclitics (markers that only occur noun phrase finally) count as postpositions in Grambank. This means that phonological boundness is not relevant to this question. Inpositions (which occur somewhere in between words in a noun phrase) do not count as postpositions. If there is only one postposition, this is enough for a 1 here.

Feature: Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that only mark A, S or P (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change
Clarifying Comments: The portmanteau morphemes in questions could be of person, number or TAM or markers of reciprocity, location, benefactive, direction etc. If there are affixes devoted to TAM solely these are also counted. Person markings expressing more than one argument, relative markers or relative pronouns are also included here if they form a phonological units with the root. The outcome of this affixation has to be a verb, i.e. an affix that makes a verb into an instrumental noun for example would not count. This feature is not logically triggered by the following features, but if you have coded "1" for either of these you are advised to consider whether it would also result in a "1" for this feature: 152, 151, 149, 82, 83, 84, 107, 104, 103, 147, 148, 114 and 115. The reason why there is no strict logical dependency is because while they all deal with markings on the verb, these can theoretically be other markings than prefixes, proclitics, enclitics or suffixes (reduplication, tone and suppletion). Since this kind of marking is rare, we recommend all coders being aware of this link even though it is not technically a strict dependency.
Definition: Do verbs have suffixes/enclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?

Feature: Is there productive infixation in verbs?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change
Clarifying Comments: This affix must be stem-internal and dedicated to a particular purpose, either derivational or inflectional (see general definitions for more information on productivity and dedicated functions). In keeping with existing data, if the only infixation process described for a language involves reduplication, please code 0 but be sure to note in the comments field that infixing reduplication is present.
Definition: Can infixation be used on verbs for derivational, aspectual, or voice-changing purposes?

Feature: Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that only mark A, S or P (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, oblique, TAM, negation, tense, aspect, mood, modality, valency change
Clarifying Comments: The portmanteau morphemes in questions could be of person, number or TAM or markers of reciprocity, location, benefactive, direction etc. If there are affixes devoted to TAM solely these are also counted. Person markings expressing more than one argument, relative markers or relative pronouns are also included here if they form a phonological unit with the root. The outcome of this affixation has to be a finite verb, i.e. an affix that makes a verb into an instrumental noun for example would not count. This feature is not logically triggered by the following features, but if you have coded "1" for either of these you are advised to consider whether it would also result in a "1" for this feature: 152, 151, 149, 82, 83, 84, 107, 104, 103, 147, 148, 114 and 115. The reason why there is no strict logical dependency is because while they all deal with markings on the verb, these can theoretically be other markings than prefixes, proclitics, enclitics or suffixes (reduplication, tone and suppletion). Since this kind of marking is rare, we recommend all coders being aware of this link even though it is not technically a strict dependency.
Definition: Do verbs have prefixes/proclitics, other than those that ONLY mark A, S or O (do include portmanteau: A & S + TAM)?

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Definition: Is the A participant (at least sometimes) marked by a prefix/proclitic?

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Definition: Is the O participant (at least sometimes) marked by a suffix/enclitic?

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Definition: Is the S participant (at least sometimes) marked by a suffix/enclitic?

Feature: Can the S argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: Is there a phonologically bound S argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?
Definition: Is the S participant (at least sometimes) marked by a prefix/proclitic?

Feature: Can the A argument be indexed by a suffix/enclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: Is there a phonologically bound A argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that follows its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a suffix or an enclitic)?
Definition: Is the A participant (at least sometimes) marked by a suffix/enclitic?

Feature: Can the P argument be indexed by a prefix/proclitic on the verb in the simple main clause?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: Is there a phonologically bound P argument [index](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) that precedes its verbal host (i.e. attaches to it as a prefix or a proclitic)?

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on person distinctions?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, person, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: **ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**<CR><CR>“Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for "1". This pattern includes cases referred to as person-based (alignment) split and hierarchical alignment in the literature.
Definition: Are variations in marking strategies based on person distinctions?

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: **ATTENTION! The interpretation/scope of this feature differs from the one in the previous version of the questionnaire.**<CR><CR>“Marking strategies of core participants” include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. “Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for "1". This pattern includes cases referred to as (alignment) split in the literature. <CR>Polarity (i.e. positive vs. negative distinction) does not count as a TAM category.
Definition: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on TAM distinctions?

Feature: Are variations in marking strategies of core participants based on verb classes?
Function: argument marking, core arguments, verb classification, person, number, gender
Clarifying Comments: Marking strategies include both marking by [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) and/or by flagging. The distinction between intransitive and transitive verbs is not included here. <CR>“Variations in marking strategies” include both variations in the alignment patterns, as well as variations in position (e.g. suffixing vs. prefixing) in case of indexes. <CR>Mere differences in forms of the indexes triggered by various conjugation classes are not sufficient for "1". <CR>For languages to be coded "1" the respective verb classes need to be of a substantial size (several dozens verbs or more) and ideally represent a productive pattern. <CR>The presence of verb classes whose members are often exhaustively listed in a descriptive grammar and are presented as an exceptional patterns does not qualify as "1". <CR>The patterns of interest is more common with intransitive verbs and include cases of the so-called active-inactive alignment (or simply: active or agentive-patientive or stative-active) in cases of differentially marked S argument. Some grammars use the terms unergative-unaccusative verbs. The pattern of interest is, however, not restricted to the S argument and variations in marking of A and P arguments are also included.
Definition: Are variations in marking strategies based on verb classes?

Feature: Can the recipient in a ditransitive construction be marked like the monotransitive patient?
Relevant unit(s): noun, NP, verb, index, case marker
Function: argument marking, core, oblique, verb classification, derivation
Clarifying Comments: GB105 is concerned with both flagging (i.e. case and adposition marking) and indexing on the verb of the respective arguments. "1" is firstly triggered by flagging. Only if there is no overt flagging for the P argument and the recipient argument, indexing is considered. "1" includes both the "double-object construction" and the "secondary-object construction" of Haspelmath (2013).<CR><CR>Consider as ditransitive only verbs expressing physical transfer of possession or mental transfer of message (give, lend, hand, feed, send, bring, show, tell, teach).<CR><CR>Consider as ditransitive verbs which allow overt expression of an agent, a theme and a recipient/addressee arguments as separate NPs. The morphological marking of these arguments (e.g. dative case vs. adpositional marking) is irrelevant for counting a verb as ditransitive.
Definition: Can recipients be treated as a transitive object, i.e. as Direct object?

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique non-pronominal NPs (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Clarifying Comments: Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is phonologically bound (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, ... Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.
Definition: Is there case marking for oblique nominal NPs ?

Feature: Are there morphological cases for oblique independent personal pronouns (i.e. not S/A/P)?
Clarifying Comments: Are independent personal pronouns morphologically marked for oblique case (i.e. not S/A/P)? Morphological case involves any type of case marking (or flagging) that is phonologically bound (affixes, clitics, tone, alternation, vowel lengthening, ...). Oblique NPs are NPs having a function other than S, A or P, e.g. dative, locative, ablative instrumental, comitative, location in time, ... Note that genitive or possessive are not seen as cases in Grambank.
Definition: Is there case marking for oblique pronouns?

Feature: Is there directional or locative morphological marking on verbs?
Function: argument marking, oblique, applicative, valency change, derivation, valency increase
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns a bound verbal marker that signals the direction or location of the event/state/action that the predicate is referencing. If the marker can be free or bound, this also counts as 1.
Definition: Can locative or direction be morphologically marked on the verb?

Feature: Are nominal conjunction and comitative expressed by different elements?
Function: argument marking, oblique, conjunction, coordination, case marking, comitative
Clarifying Comments: Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination ('John and Mary went to market') and the marking of comitative phrases ('John with Mary went to market')? This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this (to a certain extent). In some languages the only way to do nominal coordination is with a comitative phrase, i.e., the only way to say X and Y is to say X with Y. This feature aims to capture such languages (which, as they have no difference between coordination and comitatives for nouns, get a 0). To see whether an element is comitative or coordinating check for case marking, agreement etc. For example, if X is the element in question and in the dative you get 'John-DAT X Mary-DAT' then X is likely coordinating, while if you get John-DAT X Mary then X is likely comitative. Or with agreement, if you get 'John X Mary verb-PL' rather than 'John X Mary verb-SG' (just like 'John X suitcase verb-SG') then that suggests X is likely coordinating.
Definition: Is there a difference between the marking of NP coordination ('John and Mary went to market') and the marking of comitative phrases ('John went to market with Mary')?

Feature: Is there a benefactive applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Function: argument marking, oblique, valency change, applicative, benefactive, derivation, valency increase
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns a bound verbal marker that signals that the verb has a benefactive argument. The marker could be analyzed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the benefactor or benefactee. Serial-verb-constructions that include a marker of benefactive (typically the root for "give") do not count here.
Definition: Are benefactive nominals marked on the verb?

Feature: Is there an instrumental applicative marker on the verb (including indexing)?
Function: argument marking, oblique, valency change, applicative, instrumental, derivation, valency increase
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns a bound verbal marker that signals that the verb has an instrumental argument. The marker could be analysed in the language-specific case as voice, [indexing](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/indexing) or a bound pronoun. The marker doesn't have to index the instrument.
Definition: Can instruments be marked on the verb?

Feature: Can adnominal property words occur discontinuously?
Clarifying Comments: This means that a restrictively interpreted adjective is separated from the noun by some element that is not part of the nominal. For example, can you say "The man is running big" and the like to mean "The big man is running". Typically a language which allows this has extensive agreement systems so that you can still work out what modifies what in the NP without them being adjacent (i.e. the "Australian type"). NPs that are made up of several coordinated NPs that can be interpreted by the verb or other elements are not relevant here. This features aims to capture NPs where the head and modifiers can be separated. Examples of the type "I painted the house red" or "I saw the boy big" are not necessarily discontinuous, but most likely resultative or contrastive ("I saw the boy big [as opposed to before when he was small]").

Feature: What is the order of adnominal property word and noun?
Clarifying Comments: Attributive nominal modifier is roughly equal to the old term "adjective", we want to include elements that mark "adjectival" function but that might not be described as "adjectives", see feature 69. The question concerns the pragmatically neutral order(s).
Possible Values: multistate 1: ANM - N; 2: N - ANM; 3: both; 0: they cannot be used attributively

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?
Function: attribution, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, nominal classification, gender
Clarifying Comments: Do elements expressing attributive adjectival meaning receive the same treatment as verbs when verbs are used attributively, i.e. inside an NP? The adjectival roots need not take exactly all verbal marking. If there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival roots share then there is a yes here. The result need not be finite, participles would count if that is the way verbs are marked when used attributively. This means that if the language in question forms modifying verbs by participles (“running man”) and this is the same for adjectival roots (“redding man”) then there is a yes here.
Definition: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) used attributively require the same morphological treatment as verbs?

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of adnominal possessor noun and possessed noun?
Clarifying Comments: This feature focuses on the relative order of possessor and possessum in an adnominal possession construction. Coding should take into consideration only those possession constructions that are pragmatically unmarked (i.e. not focus). This feature applies to both pronominal and nominal possessors.

Feature: Is the adnominal possessive construction different for alienable and inalienable nouns?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a morpho-syntactic difference in attributive possession that can be ascribed to alienability? <CR><CR>This feature applies to constructions with both pronominal and nominal possessors. <CR><CR>Typically, inalienable possession applies to the semantic domains of body parts and kinship, but it is sometimes found in other categories that don't align perfectly with the canonical notion of 'alienability', such as part-whole relationships other than body parts, social relationships other than kinship, or things inherently linked to a person (e.g. a person's voice, mental states, or other attributes).<CR><CR>This feature targets splits in possessive marking strategy where different classes of possessum are associated with different constructions, and where one of those possessum classes includes body parts and/or kinship terms, and possibly other categories that have strong semantic associations with their owners, social relationships, or part-whole relationships.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessor?
Clarifying Comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a prefix or proclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive prefix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of prefixes or proclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to the possessor nominal/pronominal.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a prefix on the possessed noun?
Clarifying Comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a prefix or proclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the morpheme that marks possession indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that precedes and is phonologically bound to that possessed noun.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessor?
Clarifying Comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where a possessor (either nominal or pronominal) is marked with a suffix or enclitic to indicate possession of an object. This frequently takes the form of a genitive suffix on a possessor, but may also involve other types of suffixes or enclitics. Crucially, the possession must be marked by an element that follows and is phonologically bound to the possessor nominal/pronominal.

Feature: Can adnominal possession be marked by a suffix on the possessed noun?
Clarifying Comments: This feature targets a specific type of adnominal possessive construction, namely one where possession is marked by a suffix or enclitic on the possessed noun. In some cases, the possessive suffix indexes agreement categories of the possessor. Crucially, the possession must be marked by a phonologically bound element that follows and is phonologically dependent on the possessed noun.

Feature: Are there special adnominal possessive pronouns that are not formed by an otherwise regular process?
Clarifying Comments: This feature identifies phonologically independent possessive pronouns that are not formed by the application of regular possessive marking to more general pronominal forms. Instead, languages that qualify for a (1) code for this feature will form at least some possessive pronouns through some process other than the usual possessive marking, or, frequently, with suppletive forms. Note that special adnominal possessive pronouns are most commonly found in the 1st and 2nd person.<CR><CR>To qualify as 'special adnominal possessive pronouns', the possessive pronouns must not be identical to the pronominal forms used for core arguments. It is not necessary for the possessive pronouns to be dedicated solely to the function of possession, provided that the process through which it is formed is not a regular possession marking process in the language.

Feature: Are there possessive classifiers?
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns whether there exists an independent classifier system in possessive constructions that is not related to the other classifier systems such as the gender/noun class of the language or numeral classifiers. <CR><CR>We are concerned with markers that signal the nature of the possessor or the possessum (possessor classifiers/possessed classifiers), and the relationship between them (relational classifiers). This feature applies to both pronominal/nominal possessors and markers which are bound or free. Possessive classifiers need not be obligatory, it can also be possible to construct possessive phrases without possessive classifiers.<CR><CR>Differences in the expression of individual, joint, separate and group possession is not relevant here.

Feature: Are causatives formed by affixes or clitics on verbs?
Function: causative, valency change, derivation, valency increase
Clarifying Comments: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer subject that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are targeted by this question. This question targets phonologically bound causative markers.
Definition: Are causatives formed by bound affixes/clitics?

Feature: Is there a causative construction involving an element that is unmistakably grammaticalized from a verb for 'to say'?
Function: causative, valency change, derivation, valency increase
Clarifying Comments: A causative is a valency increasing operation that introduces a causer subject that makes a non-subject argument do or become something (e.g. 'x lies' -> 'y lay x' = 'y causes x to lie'). Note that both causatives adding an argument to a transitive clause (I drink milk -> x causes me to drink milk) and those adding an argument to an intransitive clause (I sit -> x causes me to sit) are included in this feature. This question targets causative constructions that feature an element that clearly originated as a verb that means or meant 'to say' (e.g. 'I said for the stone to fall' to mean 'I made the stone fall').

Feature: Is there a distinction between inclusive and exclusive?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a pronoun or other marker that explicitly marks the inclusion of an interlocutor? This feature is not restricted to the pronominal system but includes person indexing as well. If inclusive is marked overtly in either the pronominal system or through verbal marking this is sufficient to trigger a (1) for this feature, even if exclusive has no overt morphological marking.

Feature: Is there an inclusory construction?
Clarifying Comments: Definition: a plural NP that would be expressed in English by an expression of the type ‘Harald and I talked’ or ‘Harald and us talked’ is expressed by a construction of the type [superset: pronoun] [set: noun/Proper noun], e.g. ‘we.two Harald talked’ / ‘we Harald talked’, respectively. Note: In some languages this would be expressed by associative duals/plurals, e.g. Harald-AssDu / AssPl talked’ for ‘[Someone and] Harald talked’, though this tends to be used for non-first-person groups only. It is structurally different in that no part of the associative dual/plural construction refers directly to the superset. Clarification: the element expressing the superset could be either a free pronoun or a bound pronoun. Example (Bininj Gun-wok): Bulanj ngani-wam / [Name] 1duExcl-goPP / ‘Bulanj and I went.’

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that includes a form that elsewhere means 'surpass, exceed'?
Clarifying Comments: This feature identifies languages that have a comparative construction that involves a form (usually a verb form) meaning 'surpass' or 'exceed'. Typically, the standard of comparison is the direct object, the thing which is being compared to that standard is the subject, and there are two predicates: one expressing 'surpass/exceed', and one carrying relevant lexical information about the property under comparison (e.g. "Ronald exceed be-tall Julia"). <CR><CR>Though this typical structure is quite common in languages that have a 'surpass/exceed' comparative construction, only the use of a 'surpass/exceed' form is required for this feature; it is not necessary for the standard to occur as a direct object or the thing being compared to serve as the subject in order to trigger a 1 value. The order of these predicates is not relevant for this feature, nor whether the property word is a verb or an adjective. The predicate expressing 'surpass/exceed' must also have functions besides comparison.

Feature: Can comparatives be expressed using two conjoined clauses?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a comparative construction comprised of two conjoined clauses? Specifically, this construction must involve two conjoined clauses, one with the standard-NP and one with the comparee-NP. These NPs have the same function in the clauses. Note that many if not most languages can juxtapose clauses in order to make comparisons (e.g. English "She is nice and he is not nice"). Here we are focused on languages that have a dedicated comparative construction with this structure.

Feature: Is there a comparative construction with a standard marker that elsewhere has neither a locational meaning nor a 'surpass/exceed' meaning?
Relevant unit(s): verb, auxiliary, particle, clause, adjective, adposition
Clarifying Comments: This question is focused on comparative constructions that have a dedicated marker for the standard of comparison that does not fall under the umbrella of the locational comparative (GB266) or surpass/exceed comparative (GB255). Note that a language may have multiple comparative constructions, including a non-locational, non-surpass/exceed comparative as well as constructions that are described by those features.<CR><CR>Crucially the dedicated marker in this construction must not elsewhere have a surpass/exceed meaning or a locational meaning. It may, however, have other functions (e.g. temporal adverb or conjunction, among other possibilities). It is irrelevant whether this marker is phonologically free or not or whether it triggers agreement in case, gender, etc. <CR><CR>Historically, comparative constructions with dedicated markers (sometimes called "particle comparatives") grammaticalize from constructions of conjoined clauses. An example of a particle comparative would be the Germanic languages, such as English "than". Note that the marking of the property word is not relevant here (i.e. "tall-er").

Feature: Is there a bound comparative degree marker on the property word in a comparative construction?
Clarifying Comments: This feature focuses on the presence of a bound marker of comparative degree on the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. -er in English "tall-er"). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. "Maria is taller than John") but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. "Maria is taller"). This feature requires the degree marker to be phonologically bound to the property word.

Feature: Is there a non-bound comparative degree marker modifying the property word in a comparative construction?
Clarifying Comments: This feature focuses on the presence of a phonologically non-bound marker of comparative degree that modifies the property word in a comparative construction (e.g. French "plus grand"). We specifically focus on comparative constructions where the standard of comparison is overtly expressed (e.g. meanings like "Maria is taller than John") but also count clearly comparative forms where the standard of comparison is null/implied/inferred from context (e.g. meanings like "Maria is taller"). The comparative constructions of interest express superiority (as in the French and English examples above), not inferiority (e.g. meanings like "John is less athletic than Maria").<CR><CR>This feature requires that the degree marker modify the property word, but not be phonologically bound.

Feature: Is there a comparative construction that employs a marker of the standard which elsewhere has a locational meaning?
Function: comparison, predication, argument marking, oblique, locative
Clarifying Comments: This feature identifies comparative constructions that mark the standard of reference with an element that is otherwise locational or benefactive in meaning. In these constructions the standard NP is invariably constructed with a marker that also has a locational/adverbial function. Please note that benefactive markers are included here, following Stassen's category of locational comparatives. The marker of the property word is irrelevant for this feature (i.e. "tall-er").

Feature: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?
Relevant unit(s): clause, verb, adjective, noun, case marker, NP
Function: control, argument marking, core, oblique, verb classification
Form: special construction, flagging, indexing, conjugation, declension
Clarifying Comments: In a number of languages, predicates referring to uncontrolled events or states are encoded differently from those that refer to controlled events. Often, such a distinction surfaces in predicates referring to sensations (such as hunger, thirst, pain, cold, cramps, sleepiness ...), emotions (anger, happiness), or cognitive states (forgetting, remembering). Such uncontrolled predicates may be found in special constructions, different case frames ('sleep hits me', 'cramp footgrabs me'), they may form a special conjugation class of verbs or adjectives, there may be a dedicated (modal) marker for control vs. non-control, etc. The existence of verbal derivations such as passive or causative does not count as "1" here.
Definition: Is there a morpho-syntactic distinction between predicates expressing controlled versus uncontrolled events or states?

Feature: Are there definite or specific articles?
Clarifying Comments: An article is a marker that accompanies the noun and expresses notions such as (non-)specificity, (in)definiteness and information status (new or given status). Sometimes these notions of specificity, definiteness and information status are summed up in the term "identifiability". Articles cannot occur independently, though they might be homophonous with pronouns or numerals that can. A language does not necessarily have both a non-specific/indefinite and a specific/definite marker. These markers often stem from very different sources (numerals and demonstratives) and need not be similar in formal expression or position.<CR><CR>Formal expression is irrelevant; articles can be free, bound, or marked by suprasegmental markers such as tone.<CR>Articles are different from demonstratives in that demonstratives occur in a paradigm where there are markers that have a clear spatial deictic function. As demonstratives can grammaticalize into definite or specific articles, they form a natural continuum making it hard to define discrete categories. Articles are more grammaticalized, i.e. are often obligatory in certain contexts that require definite or specific reference. Definite or specific articles can also grammaticalize from pronouns meaning 'a certain'. As articles necessarily accompany nouns, it is in these cases that it is necessary to investigate whether the marker can occur independently or not; if it can it is most likely a pronoun and not an article. Articles can be homophonous with pronouns and demonstratives, and also with classifiers.
Definition: Are there definite or specific articles?

Feature: Are there prenominal articles?
Form: word order, declension, particle, paradigm, prefixation
Clarifying Comments: All questions concerning order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order. Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus.

Feature: Do indefinite nominals commonly have indefinite articles?
Clarifying Comments: In this question we need explicit support that indefinite NPs do/do not commonly occur with an indefinite/non-specific article. Indefinite articles can be homophonous with demonstratives, the numeral 'one' or classifiers.
Definition: Is an indefinite NP obligatorily accompanied by an indefinite (or non-specific) article?

Feature: Are there postnominal articles?
Form: word order, declension, particle, paradigm, suffixation
Clarifying Comments: All questions concerning order of elements aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order. Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus.

Feature: Are there three or more distance contrasts in demonstratives?
Clarifying Comments: Demonstratives are markers of a small set. This doesn't have to be only Euclidean distance (meters, inches etc.), it could also be concerned with near or far in relation to the interlocutors (cf. Wolof). If the system of demonstratives includes a marker that is anaphoric this does not count as a third distance.
Definition: Is there an opposition between three or more distance terms in the demonstrative system?

Feature: Do demonstratives show a visible-nonvisible distinction?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a distinction visible-non-visible when referencing to items that are in the same relative distance, i.e. it is not relevant that demonstratives denoting far away reference often also imply non-visibility.
Definition: Is the opposition visible-non-visible marked on demonstratives?

Feature: Do demonstratives show an elevation distinction?
Clarifying Comments: Elevation is concerned with how high up or low an object is, altitude.
Definition: Is elevation morphologically marked in demonstratives?

Feature: Is there an overt verb marker dedicated to signalling coreference or noncoreference between the subject of one clause and an argument of an adjacent clause ("switch reference")?
Clarifying Comments: Is there an overt marker, usually on the verb, that marks whether the argument has the same/different referent as an argument of the following clause? Some languages (e.g. Kashaya) signal switch reference by using different allomorphs of TAM markers depending on whether the subject of the following clause is the same or different. Some systems (e.g. Southeastern Pomo) only have special morphology to indicate different subjects, whereas the marker that is used for same subjects can also be used for some combinations of clauses with different referents.
Definition: Is there a morphologically-marked switch reference system?

Feature: What is the order of adnominal demonstrative and noun?
Clarifying Comments: Like all questions concerning order of elements, only the pragmatically unmarked orders are targeted.

Feature: Are there demonstrative classifiers?
Clarifying Comments: Please note, this does NOT concern agreement with the noun class but a separate nominal classification system. This question concerns whether there exists a independent classifier system in demonstratives that is not related to the gender/noun class systems. This classifier system can however be symmetrical with numeral, possessive or verbal classifiers.

Feature: Are nouns reduplicated?
Clarifying Comments: The repetition of phonological material within a word for semantic or grammatical purposes is known as reduplication. In order for there to be a (1) here reduplication needs to be a productive pattern. Both full and partial reduplication count. The outcome of the process is not relevant, it is the part-of-speech of the roots that matter. As for the distinction between reduplication and repetition we follow the definitions used most often in the literature, i.e. basically Gil (2005): repetition is unconstrained by grammar, can take larger units than words, has an iconic interpretation and can result in more than 2 copies. Reduplication on the other hand is constrained by grammar, usually only concerns 2 copies, is a word-internal process and doesn't necessarily have an iconic interpretation. The reduplicated elements need not be identical with respect to tone.

Feature: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?
Clarifying Comments: The repetition of phonological material within a word for semantic or grammatical purposes is known as reduplication. In order for there to be a (1) here reduplication needs to be a productive pattern. Both full and partial reduplication count. The outcome of the process is not relevant, it is the part-of-speech of the roots that matter. As for the distinction between reduplication and repetition we follow the definitions used most often in the literature, i.e. basically Gil (2005): repetition is unconstrained by grammar, can take larger units than words, has an iconic interpretation and can result in more than 2 copies. Reduplication on the other hand is constrained by grammar, usually only concerns 2 copies, is a word-internal process and doesn't necessarily have an iconic interpretation. Reduplication is a productive pattern, a few examples of repetition of phonological material does not necessarily constitute evidence of reduplication. The reduplicated elements need not be identical with respect to tone. Word classes other than verbs and nouns that are subject to reduplication include adjectives (red-red) or adverbs (daily-daily). The element reduplicated in the feature needs to consistitute a phonological word (i.e., a reduplicated affix does not count).
Definition: Are elements apart from verbs or nouns reduplicated?

Feature: Are verbs reduplicated?
Clarifying Comments: The repetition of phonological material within a word for semantic or grammatical purposes is known as reduplication. In order for there to be a (1) here reduplication needs to be a productive pattern and the copies need to be adjacent. Both full and partial reduplication count. The outcome of the process is not relevant, it is the part-of-speech of the roots that matter. As for the distinction between reduplication and repetition we follow the definitions used most often in the literature, i.e. basically Gil (2005): repetition is unconstrained by grammar, can take larger units than words, has an iconic interpretation and can result in more than 2 copies. Reduplication on the other hand is constrained by grammar, usually only concerns 2 copies, is a word-internal process and doesn't necessarily have an iconic interpretation. The reduplicated elements need not be identical with respect to tone.

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an agent noun from a verb?
Clarifying Comments: An agent nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an agent of an action. In English, we can exemplify this with the productive "-er" suffix (_baker, fisher, gardener_ etc). There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "person" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.
Definition: Is there a productive morphologically marked Agentive nominalization (sing-er)?

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an object noun from a verb?
Clarifying Comments: An object nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes the object/result of an action. There needs to be productive derivation. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "thing" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.
Definition: Is there a productive morphologically marked Object nominalization (sing; song)?

Feature: Is there a productive morphological pattern for deriving an action/state noun from a verb?
Clarifying Comments: An action nominalization is a new construction that is derived from a verb and that functions like a noun, and denotes an action or state. In English, we can exemplify this with "the enemy’s **destruction** of the city" Arrive -arriving would also serves as an example, or 'La concentracio´n de Sherlock Holmes duro´ cinco horas' in Spanish (‘Sherlock Holmes’ concentration lasted five hours’). There needs to be productive derivation, but they can also refer to states or events - not just actions. Compounds of the verb root and a noun meaning "action/state/event" is likely not an action nominalization, bring it up for discussion if this is the only available construction that is mentioned in the descriptive material.
Definition: Is there a productive morphologically marked Action/state nominalization (arrive-arrival)?

Feature: Is there a large class of nouns whose gender/noun class is not phonologically or semantically predictable?
Clarifying Comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. This feature asks whether there is a large or open class of nouns whose gender/noun class assignment is not predictable based on phonology or semantics. In other words, such a class will appear to be assigned arbitrarily.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where sex is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying Comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether biological sex is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their biological sex for this feature to be coded (1). That is, sex must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where shape is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying Comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the shape of an object is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their shape for this feature to be coded (1). That is, shape must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where plant status is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying Comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether belonging to the kingdom of plants is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for nouns that refer to plants to be classified in certain gender categories for this feature to be coded (1). That is, plant status must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment.

Feature: Is there a gender system where a noun's phonological properties are a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying Comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the phonological properties of the noun are one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their phonological properties for this feature to be coded (1). That is, some phonological property of a noun must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Examples of phonological properties that may play a role in gender/class assignment include tone or initial consonants. Note that noun class/gender morphology may create phonological similarities across members of a certain noun class or gender; however, this is not sufficient for a (1) coding for this feature. Phonological properties must contribute to the categorization of nouns to classes/genders, rather than simply result from associated morphology.

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 2nd person independent pronouns?
Clarifying Comments: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for second person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a (1) code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of second person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for second person singular, but not second person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular second person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.

Feature: Is there a male/female distinction in 1st person independent pronouns?
Clarifying Comments: This feature asks whether the independent pronoun forms used for first person differ according to the sex of the referent. Specifically, languages that qualify for a (1) code for this feature will include a distinction between male and female forms in at least some categories of first person independent pronouns. Pronouns that contrast in gender categories other than male/female sex are not sufficient to satisfy this criterion. In many languages this contrast occurs only in the singular pronouns; that is, there is a contrast between male and female forms for first person singular, but not first person plural (or dual, or any other non-singular number category). In some languages there is a contrast in multiple number categories, including singular and some non-singular number categories. It is uncommon for a language to have a male/female contrast in non-singular first person pronouns, but not in the singular pronouns, however such languages also satisfy the criteria for this feature.

Feature: Is there a gender/noun class system where animacy is a factor in class assignment?
Clarifying Comments: A noun class/gender system categorizes nouns for the purposes of grammatical agreement with other constituents in the nominal domain or with verbs, complementizers, or adpositions. Gender/noun class assignment may be based on one or several factors. This feature focuses on whether the animacy of a noun is one of these factors for a given language. There must be a clear preference for certain nouns to be classified in certain gender categories as a result of their animacy for this feature to be coded (1). That is, animacy must be a relevant factor in the assignment of gender; however it does not need to be an absolute deciding factor or the only relevant factor in gender/class assignment. Note that while (biological) sex is generally associated with animate referents, a gender system that makes a distinction between male and female is not necessarily sufficient to trigger a (1) here. A gender system in which animacy is a relevant factor will often make a distinction between human or animal referents and non-living referents, and animate status may be extended to culturally important non-living entities (e.g. mythological figures) or objects (e.g. celestial bodies). A human/non-human distinction is sufficient for a (1) code.
Definition: Is animacy (without reference to sex)  a relevant category in the noun class/gender system?

Feature: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying Comments: Gender is defined as a fixed, closed class system of classes that nouns fall into, as opposed to noun classifiers which are more open and tend to be therefore larger in number.  This question is about whether adjectives (defined semantically as 'adnominal property words') show agreement with gender of nouns they modify.  This be true for more than a small class of semantically restricted adjectives; English 'blond' v. 'blonde' for example would not be enough to answer 1 for the question.  Code 1 even if it is restricted in a particular context, such as in the plural.

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying Comments: Demonstratives can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class.

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying Comments: Articles can agree in gender/noun class with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for gender/noun class.

Feature: Can augmentative meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Clarifying Comments: Can augmentative function (i.e. larger size) be marked by a shift of nominal class? This needs to be a productive pattern. The system of nominal modification referred to in this question is not restricted to gender/noun class systems only. Augmentative function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode larger size.

Feature: Can diminutive meaning be expressed productively by a shift of gender/noun class?
Clarifying Comments: Can diminutive function (i.e. smaller size) be marked by a shift of nominal class? This needs to be a productive pattern. The system of nominal modification referred to in this question is not restricted to gender/noun class systems only. Diminutive function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode smaller size.

Feature: Is there a phonologically or morphosyntactically definable class of ideophones that includes ideophones depicting imagery beyond sound?
Clarifying Comments: Ideophones are marked words that depict sensory imagery, e.g. 'glimmer', 'twiddle, 'tinkle'. In some languages, ideophones may have different morphosyntactic characteristics from other word classes (e.g. they have different morphology, or they have no morphology at all while other classes do; or they may be extremely free when it comes to word order, in comparison to other words). They may also feature sounds that are not present anywhere else in the language. Every language probably has ideophones, but not every language has a very well defined class of ideophones. If an author doesn't mention anything at all about ideophones in an otherwise relatively comprehensive grammar, this is probably because ideophones are not a very well defined category and this question can be coded as 0 in these cases.

Feature: Is there a logophoric pronoun?
Clarifying Comments: Logophoric pronouns are used distinguish reference to an individual whose speech or thought or feeling is being reported from other third-person referents. Unsurprisingly, then, logophoric pronouns are commonly found in reported speech contexts. This question concerns the existence of an anaphoric pronoun that specifically receives its referential identity from the 3rd person subject of the superordinate clause in a reported speech construction (i.e. the speaker/thinker/feeler). In other words, is there a special pronominal form that occurs in the complement clause of a speech or thought verb, that designates the subject of the speech/thought verb as its referent (as opposed to any other 3rd person referent)?

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by intonation only?
Clarifying Comments: We are looking for intonation only and no other markers in the clause which signals polar interrogation (such as a polar interrogative particle). Intonation is our focus, and not tone, because tone is a particle and bound to the constituent whereas intonation is not.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a special word order?
Clarifying Comments: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative.  There is allowed to be a different intonation from declarative sentences.

Feature: Is there a clause-initial polar interrogative particle?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a particle that occurs at the beginning of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions)?  (definition taken from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').

Feature: Is there a clause-final polar interrogative particle?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a particle that occurs at the end of the clause that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions)?  (definition taken from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').

Feature: Is there a polar interrogative particle that most commonly occurs neither clause-initially nor clause-finally?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a particle that is dedicated to marking questions that ask for the equivalent of a 'yes' or 'no' answer (as opposed to content questions) that most commonly occurs in the middle of the clause, neither initially nor finally?  (definition taken from WALS chapter 116, 'Polar questions').

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by a question particle and verbal morphology?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a polar interrogative construction in the language that consists of a combination of verbal morphology and a particle? This feature is concerned with constructions where these two elements are the only markers of polar interrogation, there should not be any other markers such as V-Not-V etc. Note that even a lack of finiteness can be considered as a marker of polar interrogation. Furthermore, tone (not intonation) is not included under 'particle' here. A special intonation is often present in polar interrogative clauses, if it occurs or doesn't occur in this construction has no effect on the coding.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by overt verbal morphology only?
Clarifying Comments: There is no other marker in the clause that signals polar interrogation, not even lack of finiteness compared to the affirmative, but intonation may also be different between questions and declarative statements.

Feature: Can polar interrogation be marked by tone?
Clarifying Comments: This feature deals with the presence or absence of a construction where the only difference between the interrogative and the declarative is marked by tone. Please note tone (not intonation) is the focus here which is a particle and bound to the constituent.

Feature: Is there an interrogative verb for content interrogatives (who?, what?, etc.)?
Clarifying Comments: Interrogative verbs are verbs that include a semantic wh-element. In other words, the semantic content of interrogative verb roots includes an element equivalent to a content question (also called a wh-element), e.g., meaning 'to do what' or 'to be who'. The wh-element needs to behave like a verb in the language, e.g., if the language is English, it should take verbal morphology, appearing, e.g., as in 'you what-ed yesterday?' (to mean 'you did what yesterday?'). The feature does not include verbs of asking or interrogative forms created through affixation of interrogative markers to non-interrogative verb roots.

Feature: Do (nominal) content interrogatives normally or frequently occur in situ?
Clarifying Comments: In situ means the normal position for a non-interrogative NP in the same participant role. This question is concerned with the use of in-situ content interrogative nominals as a general question construction. This question should be answered yes (1) if questions formed with in-situ interrogatives are pragmatically unmarked and are used commonly (e.g. not only in restrictive contexts such as echo questions or constructions with multiple interrogatives).

Feature: Is there a count/mass distinction in interrogative quantifiers?
Clarifying Comments: For example, English contrasts 'how many' versus 'how much'.

Feature: Do verbs classify the shape, size or consistency of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?
Clarifying Comments: This questions aims at capturing verbal classifier systems, these systems are not based on agreement with the noun class system (Aikhenvald 2000:149). The system can however be identical or very similar to the possessive, numeral or demonstrative classifier systems.
Definition: Do verbs classify the shape, size, consistency or position of absolutive arguments by means of incorporated nouns, verbal affixes or suppletive verb stems?

Feature: Can the verb carry a marker of animacy of argument, unrelated to any gender/noun class of the argument visible in the NP domain?
Clarifying Comments: Does animacy of an argument (S or A or P) determines the form or presence of the indexing on the verb. This system of marking has to be unrelated or not reducible to the gender/noun class system as revealed by agreement in the noun phrase.

Feature: Are there numeral classifiers?
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns whether numerals take an element that varies depending on the noun used, and is not the same as a gender system used in the language (i.e. is not numeral agreement with gender).

Feature: Is there any productive augmentative marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Clarifying Comments: This needs to be a productive pattern. Augmentative function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode larger size.

Feature: Is there any productive diminutive marking on the noun (exclude marking by system of nominal classification only)?
Clarifying Comments: This needs to be a productive pattern. Diminutive function often also entails other meanings, but it needs to minimally encode smaller size.

Feature: Is there an associative plural marker for nouns?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a marker on the noun that instead of marking additive plural "several X" marks that the reference contains entities associated with X, "X and other people/things associated with X’. This marker does not need to be bound to the noun. If the additive plural also has this function, this also counts.

Feature: Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB042<TAB>Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB042) which focusses on the bound marking of singular number.<CR><CR>Number marking can be accomplished via a marker that also has other functions, [for example obligatory articles that encode number is a 1 here](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/issues/59#issuecomment-304691348). Please alert patron when there are other functions about, as these can be tricky cases.

Feature: Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB043<TAB>Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB043) which focusses on the bound marking of dual number.

Feature: Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB044 Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB044) which focusses on the bound marking of plural number.<CR><CR>Number marking can be accomplished via a marker that also has other functions, [for example obligatory articles that encode number is a 1 here](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/issues/59#issuecomment-304691348). Please alert patron when there are other functions about, as these can be tricky cases.

Feature: Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB165<TAB>Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB165) which focusses on the bound marking of trial number.

Feature: Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB166 Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB166) which focusses on the bound marking of paucal number.<CR><CR>The paucal marker needs to be [obligatory](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/Obligatorily) in the paucal context.

Feature: Is there nonphonological allomorphy of noun number markers?
Clarifying Comments: Are there different markings of plural number that do not correlate with different markings of singular, i.e. are there new groups in the plural that are not aligned with the singular groups? The marking does not need to be on the noun itself (it can be plural word for example). The elements can include a zero-marker.

Feature: Is there productive morphological trial marking on nouns?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB319<TAB>Is trial number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB319) which focusses on the non-bound marking of trial number. Trial marking on pronouns only does not count.

Feature: Is there productive morphological paucal marking on nouns?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB320<TAB>Is paucal number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB320)<CR> which focusses on the non-bound marking of paucal number.

Feature: Are there several nouns (more than three) which are suppletive for number?
Clarifying Comments: Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group. Only so called "strong suppletion" counts here.<CR><CR>Only answer (1) if there are more than three examples of this. Body-parts and kinship terms are good place to start investigating.
Definition: Are there nouns which are suppletive for number?

Feature: Is there productive morphological dual marking on nouns?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB317<TAB>Is dual number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?<CR>](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB317) which focusses on the non-bound marking of dual number.
Definition: Can dual number be marked on the noun itself?

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for participant number?
Clarifying Comments: Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the number (singular, dual, plural etc) of a participant? The participant triggering the suppletive choice could be any of A, P, or S. Auxiliaries are also included in "verbs" for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts. There should be (reason to believe that there are) at least three verbs with participant number suppletion to count as 1.
Definition: Are there suppletive verbs for number of participants?

Feature: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying Comments: Attributive nominal modifier is roughly equal to the old term "adjective".

Feature: Can an adnominal demonstrative agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying Comments: Demonstratives can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number. NB: This concerns cases where there is a head NP different from the demonstrative. Disregard whenever the demonstrative can function as the head noun in the NP, e.g., if demonstratives function as pronouns.

Feature: Can an article agree with the noun in number?
Clarifying Comments: Articles can agree in number with the head noun even if the head noun is not overtly marked for number

Feature: Is there productive morphological plural marking on nouns?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB318<TAB>Is plural number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?<CR>](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB318) which focusses on the non-bound marking of plural number. Reduplication doesn't count.
Definition: Can plural number be marked on the noun itself?

Feature: Is there productive overt morphological singular marking on nouns?
Clarifying Comments: This is meant to capture marking on a open set of nouns, not a restricted set. Absence of plural marking or marking on the entire NP is not enough for (1) here. Nouns derived from adjectives or verbs are not relevant here. This feature is in contrast to [GB316<TAB>Is singular number regularly marked in the noun phrase by a dedicated phonologically free element?](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB316) which focuses on the non-bound marking of singular number.<CR><CR>The marker should not be primarily marking another function, such as definiteness.
Definition: Can singular number be marked on the noun itself?

Feature: Is there a phonologically free passive marker ("particle" or "auxiliary")?
Function: passive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
Clarifying Comments: Passivization is a valency reducing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets phonologically independent particles or auxiliaries marking passive clauses.

Feature: Can the agent be expressed overtly in a passive clause?
Function: passive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
Clarifying Comments: For languages with multiple passive constructions (e.g. "personal" and "impersonal" passives) this question should be answered "1" if the agent can be overtly expressed in any of these types of passive clauses.

Feature: Can verb stems alter according to the person of a core participant?
