Clarifying Comments: Do some verbs have two or more suppletive allomorphs whose distribution is conditioned by the person of an S, A, or P argument? <CR>Suppletive are allomorphs which are not similar in pronunciation, i.e. cannot be related to each other by morpho-phonological rules?<CR>The question covers both strong and weak suppletion, as well as ablaut. <CR>There must be at least **three** verbs to code 1.

Feature: Is there a dual or unit augmented form (in addition to plural or augmented) for all person categories in the pronoun system?
Clarifying Comments: A dual or unit augmented form must be present throughout the paradigm (i.e. for all person categories) for this feature to be coded as (1). Both bound and free person forms are to be considered in coding this feature. Inclusive and exclusive categories of 1st person are not considered separate person categories for the purposes of coding this feature (e.g. if a language has dual number in 3rd, 2nd, and any 1st person category it is sufficient for triggering a (1)). A dual or unit augmented form for a single person category in the paradigm is *not* sufficient for a (1) code.
Definition: Is there a dual (or unit augmented) in addition to a plural (or augmented) number category in pronouns?

Feature: Is there a gender distinction in independent 3rd person pronouns?
Clarifying Comments: This question targets the existence of a gender distinction in independent 3rd person anaphoric forms, which includes pronouns and also demonstratives. This distinction is often one of natural gender (masc./fem), but it could be animacy as well (see Corbett 1991 for further discussion of gender). For languages with no 3rd person independent pronouns a gender distinction in demonstratives would trigger a (1) here. If pronouns with inanimate referents agree with the gender/noun class of that inanimate noun that will also suffice for (1) here. If a language has a gender distinction for 3rd person pronouns but not for demonstratives, this is also sufficient for a (1) in this category.
Definition: Is there a gender distinction in 3rd person pronouns (or demonstratives, if no 3rd person pronouns)?

Feature: Are all person categories neutralized in some voice, tense, aspect, mood and/or negation?
Function: person, valency change, TAM, passive, antipassive, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns languages with obligatory indexing of the person of the argument somewhere in the clause (i.e. either on the verb or by clitics). The question asks whether the markers are deleted under certain circumstances. In order for there to be neutralization, there needs to be something to "neutralize" to begin with, i.e. languages without marking of person anywhere in the clause should be coded "0" for this feature. For this question do not consider independent pronouns.

Feature: Is there a politeness distinction in 2nd person forms?
Clarifying Comments: This feature asks whether there are different 2nd person pronoun forms that are used based on the level of respect accorded by the speaker to the addressee. In some cases polite pronouns are used to indicate a level of formality or unfamiliarity between speaker and addressee. In other cases politeness distinctions are used according to very specific social relationships between speaker and addressee, such as relative age, social status, or kinship. If multiple 2nd person pronoun forms exist in a single number category, and their use is patterned according to the level of intimacy or hierarchy of social relationship between speaker and addressee, this will suffice for a (1) code.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?
Clarifying Comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not merely pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.
Definition: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-medial for transitive clauses?

Feature: Are there serial verb constructions?
Clarifying Comments: Serial verbs are two or more verbs in juxtaposition, functioning as a single predicate, with no morphology to mark their relationship with each other. Each of the verbs is a separate phonological word but the construction as a whole is expressed in one intonational unit. Morphology is shared to a greater or lesser extent. Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.<CR><CR>TODO (from Jana): Please add a comment on whether the two verbs of an SVC must be adjacent.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?
Clarifying Comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not merely pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.
Definition: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-initial for transitive clauses?

Feature: Is the order of core argument (i.e. S/A/P) constituents fixed?
Clarifying Comments: The order is fixed if you cannot permute the order of core constituents and the verb without either i) changing the propositional content of the clause or ii) requiring intonational signalling or further elements (particles, cleft components, adjuncts).

Feature: What is the pragmatically unmarked order of S and V in intransitive clauses?
Clarifying Comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not merely pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored.

Feature: Can the S or A argument be omitted from a pragmatically unmarked clause when the referent is inferrable from context ("pro-drop" or "null anaphora")?
Clarifying Comments: This feature identifies languages that do not require a phonologically overt S or A argument expressed by a noun phrase or independent pronoun when the referent can be inferred from context. These languages are often called 'pro-drop' languages, and the phenomenon is generally referred to as 'null anaphora' or 'zero anaphora'. <CR><CR>Here 'omitted' means phonologically unexpressed (we do not intend for this feature to make any distinctions regarding the theoretical status of a null anaphor). To count as (1), pro-drop should occur where the S or A argument might otherwise be expressed by an independent pronoun or full noun phrase. Specifically, pro-drop should occur in simple, declarative main clauses. <CR><CR>Pro-drop is not mutually exclusive with indexing of the S or A argument on the verb. If, in the absence of an independent pronoun or nominal S or A, there is indexing of this argument on the verb, you may still code 1.

Feature: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?
Clarifying Comments: All questions concerning order of constituents aim to capture the pragmatically unmarked order between full NP constituents (not merely pronouns). Do not consider 'left or right-dislocation', accompanied by intonational signals or pragmatically marked constructions such as focus. If the verb phrase consists of several elements it is the lexical verb that counts and the position of auxiliaries/TAME marking elements can be ignored. Any other constituents other than the core arguments (A, P, V) of a transitive clause should be ignored.
Definition: Is a pragmatically unmarked constituent order verb-final for transitive clauses?

Feature: Is there clause chaining?
Clarifying Comments: Clause-chaining here is not just juxtapositioning of minimal clauses with no connectors, but chains of medial clauses (i.e. formally reduced clauses that do not have the full marking that usually occurs on the verb) which are dependent on a single verb that usually (but not always) occurs in a final position. This complete verb is fully specified to provide the missing categories (e.g. TAM, argument marking) for the entire clause chain. Clause chains may be referred to as topic chains, or as sequences of medial clauses/medial verbs. Crucially, this construction involves a single independent verb form, with several medial verbs that are dependent on it for full specification. Clause chains are generally used to describe simple sequences of events, and the medial verbs involved are often marked by special affixes.<CR><CR>Some analyses assert that medial verbs are coordinated, or at the very least not subordinated. However, it can be very difficult to determine this from descriptions and examples in grammars. Here we focus less on these syntactic distinctions and more on surface forms that fit the above description (sequences of stripped down verb forms dependent on a single verb for full specification), used for describing simple sequences of events.<CR><CR>In some cases clause-chaining may be difficult to distinguish from serial verb constructions. Remember that a serial verb construction involves a set of verbs or verb phrases that are typically inflected identically for TAM in a single clause, whereas clause-chaining involves a set of formally reduced clauses involving unmarked verbs, all dependent on a single fully specified verb form. Clause-chaining is also different from verb compounding, in that the verbs involved in clause-chaining all carry full semantic weight (in contrast to the light verb of verb compounding) and different arguments (e.g. objects) may occur in each clause (whereas a verb compound takes a single set of arguments as a whole). In cases where it is unclear which of these constructions is represented by the examples in the grammar, a (?) may be coded, but be sure to indicate in the comments that you were unable to determine which of these constructions is demonstrated in the relevant examples.

Feature: Is verb compounding a regular process?
Clarifying Comments: Verbal compounding is two or more verb stems acting as one phonological and grammatical word. Verb compounds share the same arguments. Languages with serial verbs can often have verb compounds too, however they might not always be described as such.<CR><CR>Serial verbs are different from clause-chaining because the verbs involved in clause-chaining lack finiteness and cannot occur independently in that form whereas serial verbs take the appropriate finiteness marking. Serial verbs are different from compounds because they can each take their own arguments whereas the roots of a compound share arguments.
Definition: Is verb compounding a regular process?

Feature: Are there verb-adjunct (aka light-verb) constructions?
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns constructions involving a non-predicating element expressing the lexical meaning of the construction, in conjunction with a semantically fairly empty verb, which enables the element to function as a predicate by providing the necessary morphology, e.g. 'eye do' for 'see'; or 'sneeze hit' for 'sneeze'. Exclude constructions that fall into the categories of verb compounding, clause-chaining, auxiliaries and serial verbs are excluded from the category of "light-verb". The verb needs to be sufficiently productive, it cannot only concern a few instances. It is uninteresting whether the predicating element is of nominal/verbal/other root. This means for example that what is described in the literature as "co-verb constructions" most likely are a subcategory of light verbs. It is also uninteresting for the definition of light-verbs whether or not the non-finite predicating element can occur outside the construction or not, both scenarios are acceptable. The category of light verbs cannot all consist of constructions describing states, there has to be at least a few dynamic events. There should also be instances where it is hard to define whether the non-finite predicating element (adjunct) is clearly nominal or not.

Feature: Is verbal predication marked by the same negator as all of the following types of predication: locational, existential and nominal?
Clarifying Comments: This feature pertains only to the negative marker itself, be it an independent particle, verb, auxiliary, clitic or affix. By non-verbal here we are referring to locational ("the dog is in the kitchen"), existential ("There is a heaven") or nominal predication ("Ursula is a witch"). Negation of possession, attributives (adjectives) capability or knowing are not included. However, it is very likely that languages that have different negation from the standard negator for these functions also make a distinction between locational/existential and standard.
Definition: Are verbal and non-verbal predicates marked by the same negator?

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessor and a possessum that is coded like a comitative argument?
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, comitative
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation. This kind of construction is also known as "conjunctional possessive". This means that the possessor is the subject, the predicate is an existential/locational/copula verb and the possessum is marked by an element marking simultaneity between clauses, or "also/too", or subordinating conjunction ("when/while"), or coordinating particle ("and"), or a comitative marker {"with"). The conjugational/comitative/coordination/topical/simultaneity marking need not be bound to the possessum-NP, but it needs to mark the possessum-NP, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant.<CR><CR>This is known as "conjunctional possessive" in the work of Stassen.

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a dative-coded possessor?
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, dative
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation. Is the possessum the subject of an existential predicative and the possessor in an oblique form marked by an element meaning "to/for" (i.e. "a car is to me") or dative case? The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for dative case, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant.<CR><CR>This is known as "dative possessive", a subcategory of "locational possessive", in the work of Stassen.

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a possessor that is coded like an adnominal possessor?
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, genitive
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation. The possessum is the subject, there is no locational or dative marking of the possessor. The possessor is instead construed as a modifier of the possessum (i.e. "my car exists"). It may be that the possessor is not construed as a adnominal possessor, but can still qualify as a "1" (for example if the S/A/P form is no different from an adnominal possessor form).<CR><CR>This is known as "genitive possessive" in the work of Stassen.

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with an S-like possessum and a locative-coded possessor?
Relevant unit(s): verb, clause, NP, case marker, adposition, index
Function: predication, predicative possession, argument marking, oblique, locative
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation. Locative possessive means a construction where the possessum is the subject of an existential/locative predicate and the possessor is in an oblique form marked by an element meaning "at/in/on" (i.e. "a car is on me") or the locational function is marked on the verb. The possessor-NP need not be overtly marked for location, it can be expressed in the verb itself, i.e. dependent versus head-marking is irrelevant.<CR><CR>This is known as "locational possessive" in the work of Stassen.

Feature: Do clausal objects usually occur in the same position as nominal objects?
Clarifying Comments: By clausal objects here we mean clauses that are directly governed by a finite verb (typically verbs of 'wanting', 'saying' etc.). In other words, complement subordinate clauses and not relative clauses. For example, 'I like apples' (nominal object) versus 'I like that you play the piano every morning' (clausal object) are in the same position (SVO). Many of the languages that do change are SOV languages that have SVO for (long) clausal objects. The question aims at discerning whether they are treated like prototypical nominal direct objects (not indirect or obliques). This is not always explicitly stated by the descriptive work, but an investigation into the examples and perhaps even appendixed text of the grammar should reveal this.
Definition: Do clausal objects occur in the same position as nominal objects?

Feature: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?
Clarifying Comments: Whatever the order in main clauses is, does it change in subordinate clauses?<CR>For example, is the order between woman/man/chases the same in 'the woman chases the man' versus 'I think that the woman chases the man'. It is sufficient for a 1 if there are different options in subordinate clauses that are not available in main clauses.
Definition: Is the order of constituents the same in main and subordinate clauses?

Feature: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts such as value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?
Function: predication, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, nominal classification, gender
Clarifying Comments: Do elements expressing predicate adjectival meaning take on verbal morphology? The adjectival roots need not take exactly all verbal marking, if there is at least some marking that verbal and adjectival roots share then there is a yes here. For example: "he runs" and "he greens".
Definition: Do core adjectives (defined semantically as property concepts; value, shape, age, dimension) act like verbs in predicative position?

Feature: Is there a copula for predicate nominals?
Clarifying Comments: We are asking if a copula can be used, when the predicate is nominal. This copula does not have to be obligatory. Nor a finite verb, it could be a demonstrative.
Definition: Is there a copula for predicate nouns?

Feature: Is there a decimal numeral system?
Clarifying Comments: Are expressions for 30 formed as 3x10, 40=4x10, 50=5x10, .., 90=9x10, or, if 30, 40, .., 90 are monomorphemic, are the expressions for 20-30; 30-40; 50-60; etc formed as 20+E(1), 20+E(2), .., 20+E(9); 30+E(1), 30+E(2), .., 30+E(9). Where E(X) means whatever the expression for X is in the language, not necessarily simplex/monomorphemic expression.

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a quinary numeral system?
Clarifying Comments: I.e. are some expressions for 6-9 formed as 5+1, 5+2, 5+3, 5+4.

Feature: Is there synchronic evidence for any element of a vigesimal numeral system?
Clarifying Comments: Are the expressions for 40 as 2x20, 60=3x20, 80=4x20, or, if 20, 40, 60, 80 are monomorphemic, are the expressions for 20-40; 40-60; 60-80; etc formed as 20+E(1), 20+E(2), .., 20+E(19); 40+E(1), 40+E(2), .., 40+E(19). Where E(X) means whatever the expression for X is in the language, not necessarily simplex/monomorphemic expression.

Feature: Is there a body-part tallying system?
Clarifying Comments: A body-part tally system is where counting starts from one hand tallying parts of the body along the arm up to the head and continues with symmetric tally points down the other side of the body. A body-tally system is distinct from other counting systems that make use of the body at least by the property that body-tally systems make use of other parts of the body apart from hand/feet/fingers/toes.

Feature: What is the order of numeral and noun in the NP?
Clarifying Comments: Consider cardinal numerals only (i.e., not ordinal numerals). It does not matter what kind of construction is required (e.g., attributive 'two books' or relative 'books that are two') or what word class the root or modifying form of that the cardinal numerals belong to, i.e., 'two-ing books' (verb) or 'two-some books' (noun) apply to this question. If some numerals go before the noun and some go after, code 3 (both orders). If there is a free choice where to place the numeral, code 3 (both orders) as well. If the order depends on some other grammatical category which is neutral with respect to pragmaticality (e.g. definiteness), code 3. If the order depends on the noun consider the order(s) that applies to an open class of nouns.

Feature: What is the order of the adnominal collective universal quantifier ('all') and the noun?
Clarifying Comments: This feature is concerned with the ordering of a universal quantifier used adnominally and the noun. We are specifically focused on the relative position of the collective universal quantifier ('all'); in languages that do not have a distinction between collective and distributive universal quantifiers ('all' vs. 'every'), a quantifier that could be translated as 'all' and has a primarily plural use will be a sufficient target for this feature.<CR><CR>There are four possible codes for this feature, reflecting the fact that the collective universal quantifier might occur strictly before or strictly after the noun, may be allowed in both of these relative positions, or may not be present in a language. A 0 code is also applicable when the language does not allow a basic construction with an adnominal collective universal quantifier and a noun (e.g. if only a floating construction is used).<CR><CR>Orders that result from constructions like quantifier float (e.g. English "The children have all come") should be disregarded for the purposes of coding this feature.

Feature: Do collective ('all') and distributive ('every') universal quantifiers differ in their forms or their syntactic positions?
Clarifying Comments: This feature identifies languages that use different forms or syntax for collective universal quantification versus distributive universal quantification. This contrasts with languages that use both the same form *and* the same syntactic position for these two types of quantification.

Feature: Can an adnominal numeral agree with the noun in gender/noun class?
Clarifying Comments: This applies to cardinal numbers primarily.

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reciprocal marker on the verb?
Function: reflexive, reciprocal, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
Clarifying Comments: This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized.
Definition: Is there morphology (include clitics) to mark a reciprocal action?

Feature: Is there a phonologically bound reflexive marker on the verb?
Function: reflexive, valency change, derivation, valency decrease
Clarifying Comments: This marker may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. It needs to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language.
Definition: Is there morphology (include clitics) to mark a reflexive action?

Feature: Can the relative clause follow the noun?
Clarifying Comments: Is the position of a non-correlative relative clause that modifies a noun immediately after its noun? E.g., '[The woman who has a green hat] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. The relative clause must immediately follow the noun and not require an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause (= be a correlative relative clause).

Feature: Can the relative clause precede the noun?
Clarifying Comments: Is the position of a non-correlative relative clause that modifies a noun immediately before its noun? E.g., '[Who has a green hat the woman] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. The relative clause must immediately precede the noun and not require an anaphoric pronoun in the main clause.

Feature: Are there internally-headed relative clauses?
Clarifying Comments: Is the noun modified by a relative clause inside a non-correlative relative clause? E.g., '[A green hat the woman has] is tall' to mean 'The woman who has a green hat is tall'. It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever). An anaphoric pronoun in the main clause should not be required. Doubly headed<CR>relative clauses are not sufficient for a yes here.

Feature: Are there correlative relative clauses?
Clarifying Comments: Is a pronoun required in the main clause that is anaphoric<CR>to the noun modified by a relative clause. For example, the pattern<CR>'[The woman who has a green hat] she is tall' counts (only) as<CR>correlative (GB330), no matter where in the relative clause the<CR>erstwhile (now replaced by an anaphoric pronoun) head noun occurs. An<CR>obligatory anaphoric pronoun in the main clause is the crucial<CR>characteristic.

Feature: Are there non-adjacent relative clauses?
Clarifying Comments: Is there a non-correlative relative clause that is not adjacent to its modified noun. For example, in 'the woman is tall [who has a green hat]', the noun (woman) is not adjacent to its modifying relative clause (who has a green hat) and so it is an example of an adjoined relative clause. It must be possible for the head noun to be any noun, not only an unspecific (pro)noun (e.g., whoever). An anaphoric pronoun in the main clause should not be required.

Feature: Is there a preposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Clarifying Comments: In verbs of thinking of knowing, is there a complementizer preposed to the complement? For example, English has a preposed complementizer 'that' ('I know that the hat is blue' / 'I think that the hat is blue'). The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free.

Feature: Is there a postposed complementizer in complements of verbs of thinking and/or knowing?
Clarifying Comments: In verbs of thinking of knowing, is there a complementizer postposed to the complement? For example, Japanese has postposed complementizer 'to'. The complementizer does not have to be phonologically free.

Feature: Is a morphological distinction between perfective and imperfective aspect available on verbs?
Clarifying Comments: This feature is concerned with bound marking of imperfective/perfective grammatical aspects. These categories could go by the name of punctual/continuous, preterit/progressive etc. The answer could be "yes" even if it's only one that is overtly marked, i.e. if imperfective is by affix and perfective by auxiliary for example. Please take notice that GB310 and GB86 are not covering exactly the same functions, they cover more grammatical aspects than punctual/continuous. If this marking is only relevant for a small subset of verbs, alert patron and discuss.<CR><CR>If this distinction is only available in some TAM-conditions, this counts as well. For example, if there isn't an aspectual distinction in the past but only in the present, this still triggers a '1'.
Definition: Is a distinction between punctual/continuous aspect available as a morphological choice?

Feature: Can aspect be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying Comments: This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.

Feature: Can aspect be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying Comments: This feature covers all grammatical aspects (internal temporal constitution of event/action/state) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such).  These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.<CR><CR>A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Is there grammatical marking of direct evidence (perceived with the senses)?
Clarifying Comments: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's direct sensory evidence for some event or action. Visual evidence is frequently encoded with a direct evidential, however this type of evidentiality may also include auditory or other non-visual categories of sensory evidence. This question should be answered yes (1) if the language has a single direct evidential or any number of sensory evidentials.

Feature: Is there grammatical marking of indirect evidence (hearsay, inference, etc.)?
Clarifying Comments: This question is concerned with the marking of evidentiality related to the speaker's indirect, non-sensory evidence for some event or action. Indirect evidentiality usually involves inference from physical evidence or second-hand knowledge such as hearsay. This question should be answered yes (1) if there is a single category of indirect evidentiality or any number of inferential or reportative evidential categories.

Feature: Is there a difference between imperative (prohibitive) and declarative negation constructions?
Clarifying Comments: Is the negative construction for declarative negation ("I don't drink") different from negative imperative ("don't drink!"). This feature covers more than only different negators: different order, loss of finiteness or addition of new elements would also suffice. If the analysis of the language-specific researcher results in two different forms for negative imperative and prohibitive, then we are only concerned with the construction that is fulfilling the traditional imperative function here.
Definition: Is there a difference between imperative and declarative negation?

Feature: Can polar interrogation be indicated by a V-not-V construction?
Clarifying Comments: This feature concerns polar interrogative constructions where the main verb is repeated, one time in the affirmative form and another in the negated. This is independent of the negation marking system of the language, it may be by suffixes, auxiliaries, suppletion etc. The negated form need not be in second place, it could be first as well.

Feature: Can mood be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying Comments: This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and "reality" and/or speakers' attitude toward what they are saying) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.<CR><CR>While negation can be considered a grammatical mood, it is not included in this feature.<CR><CR>A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to mood?
Clarifying Comments: This question is concerned with bound marking on the verb root that denotes grammatical mood. This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and "reality" and/or speakers' attitude toward what they are saying) and aims to capture phonologically bound elements.

Feature: Can mood be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying Comments: This feature covers all grammatical moods (the relationship between the referred event/state/action and "reality" and/or speakers' attitude toward what they are saying) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.<CR><CR>While negation can be considered a grammatical mood, it is not included in this feature.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-initially?
Clarifying Comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood (and possible more). This includes prefixes on verb-initial clauses, but suffixes on clause-initial verbs do not count as clause-initial negation. Do not include elliptical constructions of the kind 'Not Mary'. If the negator consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-initial, this is sufficient to count as clause-initial negation.<CR><CR>Please note, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or focus constructions.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an affix, clitic or modification of the verb?
Clarifying Comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation, i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood (and possible more). The marker has to form a phonological unit with the root, be it by affixation, cliticisation, suppletion, reduplication, tone etc. If the verb that the marker is attached to is described as an "auxiliary", this also counts but it is advisable to bring this up for discussion.
Definition: Is negation marked morphologically on the verbs?

Feature: Can standard negation be marked clause-finally?
Clarifying Comments: This feature refers to Standard Negation (SN), i.e. the construction that marks negation of dynamic verbal predicates in declarative mood (and possible more). This includes suffixes on verb-final clauses, but prefixes on clause-final verbs do not count as clause-final negation. Do not include elliptical constructions of the kind "'Pete didn't". If the negator<CR>consists of two obligatory elements and only one is clause-final, this is sufficient to count as clause-final negation.<CR><CR>Please note, we're concerned with the order of the negative marker when the clause has its canonical intransitive or transitive word order, i.e. not cases of argument omission or focus constructions.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns negative words that function as auxiliary verbs, in that they inflect as verbs but occur only with other verbs. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably what this set of features is aimed for.<CR><CR>A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite"/"connegative" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Can standard negation be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns negative words that do not inflect and are not bound to the verb. This question aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do not inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, environment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analysed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. <CR><CR>This question should be answered yes (1) if negation is marked by a phonologically independent, non-inflected word (particle), regardless of whether any other strategy can also be used to mark negation (e.g. a language that uses double marking of negation through both a particle AND a verbal affix would be coded as yes (1)).

Feature: Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?
Clarifying Comments: This question is concerned with whether there is an overt marker dedicated to signaling the distinction between temporally simultaneous and sequential actions. If sequential meaning is a secondary function of an imperfective aspect this does not count; it must be indicated by a devoted marker. The language does not need to express both sequential and simultaneous temporal relationships overtly; one marker devoted to either function will do.
Definition: Is there a morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses?

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to future tense?
Clarifying Comments: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of future tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.<CR><CR>Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for [GB082](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB082), but (0) for this feature (GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas "present tense" has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.<CR><CR>It can be hard to distinguish future tense from different modal categories, after all if something is in the future it has not yet occurred and can be construed as something wished for, planned, intended etc rather than actually on the concrete timeline of events. This is why it's necessary to take extra notice on sections on mood, especially irrealis, when coding for future tense.<CR><CR>If a language only has future tense under negation, this does not count for this feature. It needs to be present for affirmation as well. [This was brought up in this issue thread.](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/issues/62). The reason for this is that conditions such as "only under negation" are likely to give rise to quite different analysis by different linguists (hence hard to ensure comparability) and might also be overlooked. If we were to treat such marginal cases as "1" we would most likely have to go back to a lot of the cases that were coded as "0" and re-evaluate their coding more thoroughly.
Definition: Is there future tense regularly morphologically marked on the verb?

Feature: Are there multiple past or multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from Time of Reference?
Clarifying Comments: This question aims at capturing productive marking of tense that makes distinctions into remoteness of time in relation to the point of reference or utterance. The actual marking can tonal, verbal affixation, suppletion or any other means of marking. The markers need not be dedicated to tense marking in the same way that GB083, GB084, GB110, GB121 and GB521 are.

Feature: Can tense be marked by a non-inflecting word ("auxiliary particle")?
Clarifying Comments: This feature covers all tenses (present, past and future) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that do no inflect (i.e. do not change form depending on arguments, TAM-enviroment or such). These markers are often described as "particles" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. This means that words such as "tomorrow" and "yesterday" do not qualify as productively marking future and hodiernal past. If there are any questions regarding this, please do bring it up with the group.<CR><CR>A crucial aspect of this feature is that the main verb should behave as it does when it is combined with other auxiliary verbs, which is often that it loses finite marking ("infinite" mood). If there are other auxiliaries in the language that modifies main verbs, consider what changes occur there. Of course, if the language is isolating and there isn't much of verbal morphology this is less relevant or possible irrelevant all together.

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking of present tense on verbs?
Clarifying Comments: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of present tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that future tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.<CR><CR>Sometimes a language will be described as having a past/non-past distinction. In this case, if there is an overt marker of non-past code the language as (1) for GB082, but (0) for [GB084 (future tense)](https://github.com/glottobank/Grambank/wiki/GB084). Future tense needs to be more dedicated to actual future reference, whereas "present tense" has less stricter demands on the scope of its function.
Definition: Is there present tense regularly morphologically marked on the verb?

Feature: Is there overt morphological marking on the verb dedicated to past tense?
Clarifying Comments: This question aims at capturing overt productive paradigms of tense. "On the verb" here means that the marker has to form a phonological unit with the verb. The marking of tense can be: affixes, clitics, suppletion, tonal marking and/or reduplication. This feature aims at capturing over marking of past tense on the verb, i.e. lack of other markings is not enough. There are instances where TAM can be expressed by a combination of an affix and auxiliary, for example some grammarians state that past tense is accomplished by a certain aspect on the verbal root and an auxiliary. If this is the productive grammatical obligatory way of expression the tense in question than such a construction is allowed to trigger yes (1) for both "on the verb "and "auxiliary". However, in the case of discontinuous marking, please contact the patron to go over details.<CR><CR>It can be difficult to distinguish perfective/perfect/punctual aspect from past tense, since past tense tends to be perfective. If this is an issue, bring it up for discussion in the group.
Definition: Is there past tense regularly morphologically marked on the verb?

Feature: Can tense be marked by an inflecting word ("auxiliary verb")?
Clarifying Comments: This feature covers all tenses (present, past and future) and aims to capture phonologically free-standing elements that inflect (i.e. change form depending on arguments, TAM-enviroment or such). These markers are often described as "auxiliary verbs" in the literature, but are also analyzed under other labels. We are after grammatical marking, i.e. dedicated, productive and obligatory marking. Pay special attention to markers described as "pronouns" that take TAM-marking, they are probably inflecting words marking tense.

Feature: Is there verb suppletion for tense or aspect?
Clarifying Comments: Are there verbs that use a different stem depending on the tense or aspect (present, past etc) form it occurs in? Auxiliaries are also included in "verbs" for the purpose of this feature. Only strong suppletion (different stem) counts.<CR>The language should have at least three cases, i.e., three verbs, to count as 'yes' (so there should be three cases exemplified or implied in the description).

Feature: Are there conjugation classes?
Function: TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, verb classification, argument marking, core, oblique
Clarifying Comments: Are there different groups of verbs that take different finiteness markers. This could also be two groups of "regular" and "irregular". Phonological rules are not considered here, we are concerned with whether there is non-phonological allomorphy of finiteness marking on verbs depending on which verb is chosen. Tonal classes are particles which may encode finiteness, and can be considered. <CR><CR>Look for finiteness markers such as:<CR>* Person : 1st, 2nd, 3rd<CR>* Number: singular, plural, dual and trial.<CR>* Gender: masculine, feminine or neuter<CR>* Tense: present, past, or future.<CR>* Aspect: perfect, perfective, progressive.<CR>* Mood : indicative, subjunctive, imperative, optative.<CR>* Voice: active, middle, or passive.

Feature: Is there a morphological antipassive marked on the lexical verb?
Function: valency change, antipassive, derivation, valency decrease
Clarifying Comments: Antipassive markers detransitivize verbs by removing the P argument or realizing it as an oblique complement. In languages that have ergative alignment, this means that the ergative argument (A) becomes absolutive (S). Antipassive markers often also have other detransitivizing functions, such as reflexivization, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative.  In practice, it is possible to define this feature as targeting any intransitivising marker that is not a reflexive, reciprocal, passive, or anticausative marker. This question targets productive phonologically bound antipassive markers on lexical verbs. Zero-marking or the removal of a transitivizing marker is not sufficient for a "1". Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here. If the antipassive marker is only applied in a limited set of probably lexicalized items, it does not trigger "1".
Definition: Is there a morphologically marked antipassive?

Feature: Are there verbal affixes or clitics that turn intransitive verbs into transitive ones?
Function: valency change, derivation, valency increase, causative, applicative
Clarifying Comments: This feature asks whether intransitive verbs can take a bound morpheme that implies the addition of just one role in the event denoted by the verb. This could be a causative affix or clitic, an applicative (benefactive, instrumental, ...), ... It has to be productive. Note that there is no dependency with GB155 here, as a language could have causatives that change a verb's valency from 2 to 3 but not from 1 to 2.

Feature: Is there a morphological passive marked on the lexical verb?
Function: valency change, passive, derivation, valency decrease
Clarifying Comments: Passivization is a detransitivizing operation that takes a transitive clause ('The dog bites the man.') and turns it into an intransitive one by promoting the P argument ('the man') to morphosyntactic S function. In the resulting intransitive clause, the former A argument ('the dog') either vanishes or adopts an oblique function: 'The man is bitten (by the dog).' 'Mediopassives' and the sort (e.g. 'x breaks the vase' > 'the vase breaks') also count as passives. This question targets phonologically bound passive markers on lexical verbs. Anything that happens with auxiliaries is irrelevant here.
Definition: Is there a morphologically marked passive construction?

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent reflexive pronoun?
Clarifying Comments: Any free form that expresses reflexive meaning counts as a reflexive pronoun. A reflexive pronoun can also be derived from regular independent pronouns with reflexive morphology (e.g. him-self in English, lui-même in French). If reflexive meaning is expressed with a body part noun, e.g. 'body' or 'head' ('They are scolding their body' to mean 'They are scolding themselves'), this also counts as "1". One reflexive pronoun (e.g. only for a certain person) is enough for "1" here.

Feature: Is there a phonologically independent non-bipartite reciprocal pronoun?
Clarifying Comments: Reciprocal pronouns are bipartite if they can be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers (e.g. each + other; two + two). So this question asks whether there are any phonologically independent reciprocal markers that cannot be synchronically analyzed as consisting of two quantifiers. These markers may indicate both reflexive and reciprocal functions. They need to be productive, not limited to a small set of verbs in the language that are probably lexicalized.

Feature: Is incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intransitivizing process?
Clarifying Comments: Noun-verb incorporation is defined as a special construction where obligatorily bare (i.e. articleless, numberless, modifierless) nouns must occur adjacent to or inside of the verb (in a fixed order). This question asks essentially, can transitive verbs become intransitive by means of noun incorporation, and is this process productive? This need not be the default productive way of intransitivizing nouns, but the process must be productive. The incorporated noun is semantically the direct object of the verb. For example: "he was painting the bike" = "he was bike-painting". Noun incorporation where the noun is acting as modifier do not count, such as "she was running like Jacob runs" = "she was Jacob-running". If it is necessary to still overtly mark the direct object, for example with a pronoun, that does not count.
Definition: Is there incorporation of nouns into verbs a productive intranisitivizing process?

Feature: Is there a class of patient-labile verbs?
Clarifying Comments: This quote from [Kulikov and Lavidas](http://www.fabula.org/actualites/typology-of-labile-verbs-focus-on-diachrony_27119.php) serves as a very good clarification. We are for this question only interested in P-labile verbs, not A-labile verbs.<CR><CR>_The term ‘labile' refers to verbs or verbal forms which can show valency alternation, i.e. changes in syntactic pattern, with no formal change in the verb. Very often (but not always) the term ‘labile' is only employed to refer to verbs (or verbal forms) which can be employed both transitively and intransitively, as in (1-2); some scholars use other, less widely accepted terms in this sense, such as ‘ambitransitive' (R. M. W. Dixon 1994) or ‘optionally transitive' (J. G. Miller 1993):_<CR><CR>_(1) English_<CR><CR> _a. John broke the vase_<CR><CR> _b. The vase broke_<CR><CR>_(2) Greek_<CR> _a. O      Janis efage   mesimeriano_<CR>    _the:NOM  Janis:NOM  ate:3SG lunch:ACC_<CR>    _‘Janis ate lunch'_<CR> _b. O        Janis   efage                _<CR>    _the:NOM  Janis:NOM  ate:3SG_<CR>    _‘Janis ate'_<CR><CR>_(1) exemplifies Patient-preserving lability (P-lability), while (2) instantiates an Agent-preserving lability (A-lability)._

Feature: Is there a notably small number, i.e. about 100 or less, of verb roots in the language?
Clarifying Comments: In languages with a small number of verbs verb-noun or verb-adjective locutions are used instead, e.g., 'do meeting' for 'meet'. If a language has a small number of verbs in this sense, typically it will says that there is a closed class of verbs and a large part of the grammar will be devoted to the constructions whereby a verb from the closed class combines with an open-class item to form the predicate in most sentences. If the grammar never remarks on the size of the verbal inventory this almost always means that the language does not have a small number of verbs in the sense of the present question.

Feature: Are different posture verbs used obligatorily depending on an inanimate locatum's shape or position (e.g. 'to lie' vs. 'to stand')?
Clarifying Comments: English would receive '0' here, as you can simply say that 'a bottle is on the table'. Dutch would be coded as '1', as you always have to specify whether an object 'stands' or 'lies' on the table (you cannot say that it 'is' on the table). Different configurations are possible, however (e.g. 'sit' vs. 'stand', 'hang' vs. 'lie' vs. 'stand'). Note that this feature does not concern morphological (or other overt) marking for position or shape, but really the use of different verbs for this purpose (in other words, suppletion). If the posture verbs are clearly dominant in frequency this is sufficient to count as 'obligatory' for the purpose of this question, even if non-posture alternatives are grammatical.

Feature: Is there an existential verb?
Clarifying Comments: Is there an element expressing existential predication, that is **different from the equative or attributive copula**? It is possible that there are more than one existential verbs making further distinctions, temporary versus permanent existence or a special marker for negative existence. Different positional verbs do not count here. The existential marker can be used for the expression of other functions, such as aspect, as long as it is not identical to the copula of identity or attribution. The existential element need not be a verb in the language in any other sense than being the existential "verb". The existence of a negative existential is not sufficient for a 1.
Definition: Is there one or more existential verb?

Feature: Can predicative possession be expressed with a transitive 'habeo' verb?
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns predicative possession, i.e. finite clauses that express an ownership relation. Is there a verb that expresses predicative possession where the possessor is the subject, the possessum the object and the verb is finite and clearly transitive. The finite element in itself need not be clearly distinct from an existential or locational predicator, the main difference is the argument structure. Transitivity is a language-specific category that needs to be investigated separately to learn whether or not the construction is transitive. In case of languages where transitivity is hard to define it might be beneficial to compare to verbs of "hold" and "grasp". It is very likely that habeo-verb constructions arise from possessive constructions where the possessor is expressed as a topic (see feature 255).<CR><CR>This is known as "have-possessive" in the work of Stassen.

Feature: Does the verb for 'see' have suppletive verb forms?
Function: verb classification, TAM, tense, aspect, mood, modality, negation, argument marking, core arguments, oblique
Clarifying Comments: This question concerns verb(s) of seeing/watching/looking, and strong suppletion in them. Suppletion is when a word is changed in such a way that the new word does not resemble the previous, for example English _went_ and _go_. If you are unsure if a form is "enough different" to count as suppletion, bring it up for discussion in the group.

Feature: Does the verb for 'come' have suppletive verb forms?
